Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Perturbation Training in Postoperative ACL Rehabilitation

Trial_Design.evidence: In this single-blind randomised controlled trial, 40 male participants who completed ACL reconstruction rehabilitation were randomised into two groups

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they were 3–9 months post-ACL reconstruction, had >80% quadriceps strength limb symmetry, no pain, full ROM, and minimal effusion.

Intervention.evidence: randomised into two groups: SAP (strengthening, agility, and secondary prevention) and SAP+PERT (SAP with perturbation training)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the impact of perturbation training on postoperative ACL rehabilitation outcomes compared to standard care.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was quadriceps strength and single-legged hop limb symmetry, measured at 1 and 2 years post-surgery.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 40 male participants who completed ACL reconstruction rehabilitation were randomised

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 1 year, quadriceps symmetry was similar between groups (SAP = 101% ± 14%, SAP+PERT = 101% ± 14%). At 2 years, SAP showed 103% ± 11% and SAP+PERT 98% ± 14% symmetry.
